responses: For the year of 2020, I'll be playing through 50(ish) games I've never beaten before. With over 1000 hours of gameplay expected across 9 platforms and 5 decades, I tried to mix in a wide variety of genres to keep things fresh throughout the year. Check the list to see if I'll be playing your favorite game! https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1JsdDfmdjaL3d-oGsuq38z_jhrvkhePF1LLz4W1dpzI4/edit?usp=sharing

commands.name: !av
responses: Wanna know how many wires are in my AV setup? Or how many splitters it takes to play GameBoy games on a PC monitor? Check the diagram here: https://gist.github.com/ghettospud/6f82f3da9d586df553757fa134278845 and the real life™ images here: https://twitter.com/ghetto_spud/status/1306375006008610817. Feel free to ask me questions about any specific components!

Wondering what kind of hardware I use to play and stream my games? Take a look at the diagram here: https://gist.github.com/ghettospud/6f82f3da9d586df553757fa134278845 to see the layout of my setup. You can also find images of everything as it situ here: https://twitter.com/ghetto_spud/status/1306375006008610817. Don't be afraid to ask questions about how everything works!

commands.name: !games
responses: I maintain a list of all the games I've streamed here: https://pastebin.com/bGjDvFDx and a tier list of my blind playthroughs here: https://pastebin.com/fRPKHM7D. You can also find a collection of all my substantial opinions on my profile: https://pastebin.com/u/ghetto_spud

commands.name: !tomato
responses: tomahto

commands.name: !potato
responses: potahto

commands.name: !blind
responses: Blind means that I know nothing about the game I'm playing and want to keep it that way. Assume all questions about the game are rhetorical, and don't hint/spoil/suggest/backseat/tip/advise/guide/recommend/remind/warn me in any way, please. I can learn how to walk on my own. Go play the game yourself if you can't keep it in your pants.

Wait! Before you send that comment, consider if it might inform me about something I don't know or understand yet, hint that I'm doing something inefficiently, or otherwise imply that I've missed something in the game you think to be obvious, crucial, or both. Maybe you feel bad for me, or frustrated that I'm not doing something the way you'd like, but please refrain from typing any messages that might include any of the above qualities. I'm playing this game for my own enjoyment, so try not to spoil anything. I assure you I’m still having fun, and I am very much still interested in figuring things out on my own.

commands.name: !github
responses: I (Spud) wrote this chatbot myself because I'm a big dork. If you fancy yourself a dork too, you can peruse the source code on GitHub here: https://github.com/ghettospud/ghetto_botato
This chatbot is © Spud Inc., which maintains an open policy of showcasing all the programming mistakes of the chatbot author here for all to see: https://github.com/ghettospud/ghetto_botato

commands.name: git --help
responses: usage: git [--help] <command> [<args>]     These are common Git commands used in various situations: add, google, pull, push, reset, status

commands.name: git add
responses: Thank you for adding your name to the list. The FBI is now en route to your location.

One of the four basic operations of arithmetic, adding was first invented on November 10, 1969 when the educational children's television series, Sesame Street, premiered on the American television station, PBS.
Adding has been deprecated. We instead recommended to subtract negative values from now on.
Nothing specified, nothing added.    hint: Maybe you wanted to say 'git add .'?

responses: Your '.' has been received. We appreciate such generosity in these trying times.

responses: Step 1 of using git: ask google how to use git

commands.name: git pull
responses: The gravity of Earth, denoted by g, is the net acceleration imparted to objects due to the combined effect of gravitational pull (from mass distribution within Earth) and the centrifugal force (from the Earth's rotation). Near Earth's surface, the pull is approximately 9.81 meters per second per second.
pull (ˈpu̇l) v. 1: To exert force upon so as to cause or tend to cause motion toward the force 2: To extract 3: To draw the support or attraction of [Middle English, from Old English pullian]

commands.name: git push
responses: Hey! Don't shove me!
